story.text: rsync is a utility to keep copies of a file on two computer systems. It is commonly found on Unix-like systems and functions as both a file synchronization and file transfer program. The rsync algorithm is a type of delta encoding, and is used to minimize network usage. Zlib may be used for additional compression, and SSH or stunnel can be used for data security - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rsync wikipedia]
- rsync is released under the GPLv3
# Tutorials

- How To Use Rsync to Sync on [https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-rsync-to-sync-local-and-remote-directories digitalocean.com]
- Examples over at [https://www.librebyte.net/en/cli/practical-examples-of-the-rsync-command/ librebyte.net]
# Over ssh

Rsync is typically used to synchronize files and directories between two different systems. For example, if the command rsync local-file user@remote-host:remote-file is run, rsync will use SSH to connect as user to remote-host. Once connected, it will invoke the remote host's rsync and then the two programs will determine what parts of the file need to be transferred over the connection.

# Daemon mode
Rsync can also operate in a daemon mode, serving files in the native rsync protocol (using the "rsync://" syntax).

> Note: this may be interesting for asynchronous uploads from the [[home server]].
# Rsync push
To sync the contents of dir1 to dir2 on the same system, type:
rsync -r dir1/ dir2
The -r option means recursive, which is necessary for directory syncing. We could also use the -a flag instead:
rsync -a dir1/ dir2

The -a option is a combination flag. It stands for “archive” and syncs recursively and preserves symbolic links, special and device files, modification times, group, owner, and permissions. It is more commonly used than -r and is usually what you want to use.

> Note: you may have noticed that there is a trailing slash (/) at the end of the first argument in the above commands. Missing that out produces unexpected results - [https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-rsync-to-sync-local-and-remote-directories digitalocean.com]
# Rsync push to remote
The following code will push a file from your local directory to a remote folder.
rsync -azP ~/dir1 username@remote_host:destination_directory

The -P flag combines the flags --progress and --partial. The first of these gives you a progress bar for the transfers and the second allows you to resume interrupted transfers. The -z flag uses zlib compression, and the -a flag treats modification dates etc and synchs recursively.
# Rsync pull
A command line to mirror of pull [[FreeBSD]] from a remote directory to a local folder might look like: - [http://www.freebsd.org/doc/en/articles/hubs/mirror-howto.html freebsd.org]
rsync -avz --delete ftp4.de.FreeBSD.org::FreeBSD/ /pub/FreeBSD/
The -v flag provides a verbose output.

# Push certain files
You don't usually want to transfer individual files with rsync, it may be better to use a simpler tool like [[scp]] for that. however in case you do:
rsync -av helios:fich1 :fich2 :fich3 :fich4 /dest/
The command above will copy the files: fich1, fich2, fich3 and fich4 from helios to the local DIR /dest.
# Rsync Research

- powershell - Watch for... - [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47682702/watch-for-changes-in-local-folder-and-upload-them-to-sftp-server stackoverflow.com]
- macos - Bash script, watch... - [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6475252/bash-script-watch-folder-execute-command/11139175#11139175 stackoverflow.com]

The [[Apache HTTP Server]] supports only rsync for updating mirrors - [http://www.apache.org/info/how-to-mirror.html apache.org]

item.text: A command line to mirror [[FreeBSD]] might look like: - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rsync#Examples wikipedia]
$ rsync -avz --delete ftp4.de.FreeBSD.org::FreeBSD/ /pub/FreeBSD/[http://www.freebsd.org/doc/en/articles/hubs/mirror-howto.html How to Mirror FreeBSD (With rsync)]
$ rsync -avz --delete ftp4.de.FreeBSD.org::FreeBSD/ /pub/FreeBSD/[http://www.freebsd.org/doc/en/articles/hubs/mirror-howto.html How to Mirror FreeBSD (With rsync)]
$ rsync -avz --delete ftp4.de.FreeBSD.org::FreeBSD/ /pub/FreeBSD/
rsync -avz --delete ftp4.de.FreeBSD.org::FreeBSD/ /pub/FreeBSD/
A command line to mirror [[FreeBSD]] might look like: - [http://www.freebsd.org/doc/en/articles/hubs/mirror-howto.html freebsd.org]
The [[Apache HTTP Server]] supports only rsync for updating mirrors.
$ rsync -avz --delete --safe-links rsync.apache.org::apache-dist /path/to/mirror[http://www.apache.org/info/how-to-mirror.html How to become a mirror for the Apache Software Foundation]
$ rsync -avz --delete --safe-links rsync.apache.org::apache-dist /path/to/mirror
The [[Apache HTTP Server]] supports only rsync for updating mirrors -[http://www.apache.org/info/how-to-mirror.html apache.org]
The [[Apache HTTP Server]] supports only rsync for updating mirrors - [http://www.apache.org/info/how-to-mirror.html apache.org]
rsync -avz --delete --safe-links rsync.apache.org::apache-dist /path/to/mirror
rsync -avz --delete --safe-links rsync.apache.org::apache-dist /path/to/mirror
